instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW: What is PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW? PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW is a line after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit for backlight that connects to the LED driver’s switch(SW) pin where it is switched to ground rapidly in order to create the boosted voltage for the backlight circuit. .
definitions.BKL_SW: What is BKL_SW? BKL_SW means “BACKLIGHT SWITCH” – DC to DC boost circuits increase voltage by putting a lower voltage, like 8 volts, through an inductor. On the other side of the inductor, it is switched to ground rapidly - on this side, you will end up with an increased voltage as a result of the switching. BKL_SW usually refers to the pin on the LED driver that is attached to the inductor. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi.

I have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with no backlight issue. The initial problem was <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>, I replaced it and got all voltages but no backlight I had output on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. the output voltages are coming and going as they like :) SCL and SDA lines are almost 5v and diode mode is good on all components. I checked all resistors and they are measuring good values. I also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>. Ideas?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Try known good compatible LCD assembly.
Any history available, how <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> got damaged?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I opened the top side of the lcd and found liquid damage on the lcd flex and connector. I replaced the connector on the lcd itself and the flex cable it flashed 2 times when on power and now i lost <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. I'll recheck the circuit again

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I reconnected all and i got <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> on the lcd side, but it just flashed and no backlight

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Is the voltage steady?
Tried known good LCD?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: When I get the 50v they are stable, but not every time I get them. When I don't get 50v to LCD , also I don't have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_BKL</SIGNAL> output from <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Also I don't have a good know LCD to try at the moment

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
50V is too high; denotes bad connection with LED strips.
Probably problem into LCD assembly.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Weird but it started working. I just connected the KB and it showed a backlight on the lcd it has been working since then. I will test it for some time, but it look great. We can close this thread Solved :)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Morning. You were right 50v it's too high. after some time testing, it lost backlight again and it gets all voltages to the lcd connector on the lcd side. LCD backlight strip replacement next step?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Replacing the LED strip is not an easy job.
You should test with compatible LCD assembly.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I've done led strip replacement and LCD only many times it's not an issue. I will open it inside maybe even the strip has liquid on it. I don't have another 2012/13 lcd assembly to try, only 2015 but they have different signals

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi. Going back to this one. I got another LCD new for testing and still no backlight.

<SIGNAL>PP5VR3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 54v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW</SIGNAL> is 11.4 and 0v on <SIGNAL>BKL_SW</SIGNAL> coming from <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>, not sure how it should be...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 54v"
Connection to LEDs strip is broken; 39V is the expected voltage.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Could it be that the lvds connector is making the issue since the LCD and lcd flex are new and all other stuff seem fine...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Possibly; do you get 54V just on its pin?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I have 54v from <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> pin 2 toward the LCD connector and on the connector itself. With the old LCD, I also got on the lcd side same

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Did you open old LCD to check the LEDs?

Just in case, check <RESISTOR>R7780</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: The old lcd was partially broken and i left it like that, but shows same with the new one. I'll check the resistor and revert

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7780</RESISTOR> it's good

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Checked voltage on its both pins too?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes both sides it's good. I resoldered <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> just to be sure and I replaced <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> also, still the same. J5250 had some liquid damage, possible issue?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: btw I checked <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> right away at the beginning of the repair and it was 3.4v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Surprise! I have a backlight when the board is out of the housing  🥳  J5250 making the issue?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hall sensor problem should disable image too, not just backlight.
Check its reaction approaching a magnet.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I replaced J5250 and it started working, which is funny cause I already had the voltages correct. After a few days of testing, all seems fine :) Thanks for the assistance :D
